So thank you!

title: Spam/predatory/papermill Journals

last_post.content:
Yes! My list of papermill journals has now more than 200 entries!

https://gist.github.com/wviechtb/e4630dec8090aac04f2eb795e2d778df

And I only started this about 2 months ago.

To celebrate this important event, I wrote a papermill journal name generator for R:

https://gist.github.com/wviechtb/a5e0c0acea15073ceada80983bc904b5

If you want to give this a spin, you could do:

source("https://gist.githubusercontent.com/wviechtb/a5e0c0acea15073ceada80983bc904b5/raw/d53c9c5d33116cdd9bb2abac778c3acf99727ce5/journal_generator.r")

replicate(100, genjournal())

Works beautifully! You may expect an email soon from the "Open Journal of Child & Adolescent Mental Disorders and Medical Investigations".

last_post.content: #emacs Book mode is an attempt at offering an interface for reading org-mode files with a clean layout. title: GitHub - sts10/tidy: Combine and clean word lists

last_post.content:
I think my most impressive open source project is Tidy, a CLI that combines and cleans large word lists.

https://github.com/sts10/tidy

It's written in #Rust and includes some interesting options, like:

* guarantee a maximum shared prefix length
* guarantee a minimum edit distance between words
* make list uniquely decodable by removing prefix words, suffix words, or using the Sardinas-Patterson algorithm
* aid list creators in avoiding certain brute force attacks

title: OOM on large monorepo project · Issue #1606 · TypeStrong/typedoc

last_post.content:
Typedoc is the de-facto standard doc generator for #TypeScript, but sadly doesn't really support monorepos. In practice it launches N instances of the TS compiler at once, then quickly runs out of memory... N is number of packages in the repo, in my case N=176 (w/ 3300+ source files). So to improve the #ThingUmbrella docs and provide better x-referencing & discoverability and other useful additions, I started working on a new experimental doc gen, still early days, but already v.promising. Really wonder how owners of other large TS projects are dealing with this, other than allocating >200GB(!) of RAM... 🤯

https://github.com/TypeStrong/typedoc/issues/1606#issuecomment-1353688993

title: Make autosuggest for mentions return followed accounts first by dariusk · Pull Request #22956 · mastodon/mastodon

last_post.content:
Made a Mastodon pull request.

In v4, there is an issue on servers that don't have elasticsearch: when a user types @ in the compose box and starts to type a name, the results they get are ordered by a popularity ranking algorithm. This is fine if you were only searching accounts you don't follow, but to me it makes more sense to FIRST return matches for accounts you DO follow as a suggestion, and then return popular accounts that you don't follow

last_post.content:
@futurebird
1) it uses the search API, so it should follow the same rules. A very vague test just now trying to search for a user and post on an instance our server is defederated from says it shouldn't work, but i'll have to double check and write tests for if an account has blocked someone. good question. had been on my mind and part of the reason why I haven't tried to pull upstream yet

2) It likely will be in the list of peer servers, but I don't know that masto uses this in any meaningful way, another thing i should check out

3) yes, unfortunately, this is something that would require the instance admin to apply

4) I tried to write something like this just using clientside javascript for eg. a bookmarklet, but the CORS rules prevented me from making the fetch to the OP server. I believe a browser extension would be able to overcome that problem, and it also looks like the search API doesn't require login (which seems bad actually) and so it might not even need to have you approve it with eg. OAuth or something like that. I have only written one extremely simple browser extension before, but this is ultimately extremely simple, basically this (and then refresh the page):

fetch(<other_instance>/api/<context_endpoint>
).then( (response) => {
response.json().descendants
.forEach( (status) => {
fetch(<search_api>/<status.url>);
}
});

in pseudo-javascript

title: [feature] fetch all replies by sneakers-the-rat · Pull Request #8 · NeuromatchAcademy/mastodon

last_post.content:
@jdp23 @liamsora @kichae @futurebird @stopthatgirl7
it certainly doesn't address the problem fully, but I'll be merging this into neuromatch.social to test soon enough: https://github.com/NeuromatchAcademy/mastodon/pull/8

It's relatively simple patch that's entirely frontend so hopefully easy to deploy on smaller instances.

Makes a button that lets you request the replies to a given post so you can see them even if no one on your instance follows the poster (ie. your instance wouldn't know about the post because of the pub/sub issues described above).

It works by using the search feature to fetch posts (as @liamsora also discovered):

Ask OP server for the context that it knows about, replies and ancestors
Submits the URLs for each of the replies to the search endpoint
Inserts posts as they are received into the redux store -> into the React component displaying the thread

It currently inserts them in a disordered way because the React component holding a thread is a single-layer component that holds expanded post & ancestors & replies. that's also related to why a thread is completely unreadable (imo) because it's rendered as a flat list rather than as a tree - which is what a thread is. Will be working on making a properly recursive component next.

Once that's done, then it should be possible to iteratively request replies in a smarter way, but that will also require another change in the way the /context endpoint works, which currently takes no arguments for subsetting and has no pagination - so therefore has relatively low hardcoded limits on the amount of replies you can request without being logged in. That will need to change to be able to request a certain depth (currently it gets the entire reply tree and then flattens it into an array) and paginate through results so that eg. you can get all the top-level replies to the request you have open, and then as you open deeper replies you get the replies to that reply, and so on....

(sorry for wall of text sort of got away from me.)

#FetchAllReplies #NestedThreads #ContextAPI #MastoDev

title: Detecting the real IP of a Cloudflare'd Mastodon instance

last_post.content:
It's trivial to determine the real IP of a Mastodon server behind Cloudflare. All it takes is one well-crafted request:

https://gist.github.com/cutiful/4f36da3ed37b24f9a7106064393f5e7f

I wonder how many instance admins using Cloudflare know about this? My hunch is most do not, because the primary justification I see for using Cloudflare here is DDoS protection.

Cloudflare won't help if the attacker knows your origin IP, and you can't hide that with Cloudflare alone, due to the nature of ActivityPub.

#MastoAdmin #InfoSec

It does exactly what it says. Write texts along a path. That's how I've created the text in this plot.

Code https://github.com/AlbertRapp/PublicTidyTuesday/blob/main/2022-w04-boardgames/2022-w04-boardgames.Rmd

Package and many more beautiful examples at https://github.com/AllanCameron/geomtextpath

title: github.com/benbrown/shuttlecra...

last_post.content:
Hello fellow citizens of the free and open web, it is me, Ben Brown. You may remember me from that social network from back when social networks were cool, or maybe from that one open source project that blew up.

Hi, it is great to see you again.

First off, corporate owned social media always sucked, we always knew it. It is past time for us to have better options.I am so glad for the #Fediverse and #ActivityPub and Mastodon and other projects for breathing new life into the indie web, where it is possible for us to own what we post and use whatever tools we want. I couldn’t resist building something!

My new project is called SHUTTLECRAFT. It social media server … FOR ONE.

What does that mean?

It is very small and lightweight open source app that runs nicely on services like Glitch, but it has most of what you need to host your own personal social media account.

It’s got a microblogging tool, to make posts. You can customize the design with HTML and CSS. You can follow people on Mastodon or other services and interact with posts and send messages. People can follow you on Mastodon, or with RSS. You run it on your own server so you own and operate the data and the code and the whole service. And you can hack the code and make it weirder so that we can all be part of a better, more diverse and more interesting web.

No billionaires or mega-corps required!

I made a 3 minute video showing how it works:
https://www.loom.com/share/a6441bcebdc64f54b5010c95eae1e180

Though this a personal project and only a few weeks old, with tons of stuff still unfinished and yet to build... you can get the code right now and run your own right now! The official site also has a 3 minute walk through of setting up an instance on Glitch. It is pretty easy!

https://shuttlecraft.net/

Or go straight to for the code:

https://github.com/benbrown/shuttlecraft

Thanks to everyone who has already tested this or sent feedback or contributed code. Y'all rule.

Own your posts!! Make it hard for them to monetize you!
